translations.chinese: 太史公曰：洋洋美德乎！

context.next: 余至大行禮官，觀三代損益，乃知緣人情而制禮，依人性而作儀，其所由來尚矣。

translations.literal: I came to the Grand Ceremonial Office and observed the gains and losses of the Three Dynasties, and thus knew that rites are established according to human feelings, and ceremonies are made according to human nature—their origins are ancient indeed.

translations.chinese: 人道經緯萬端，規矩無所不貫，誘進以仁義，束縛以刑罰，故德厚者位尊，祿重者寵榮，所以總一海內而整齊萬民也。
translations.literal: Human affairs have myriad aspects, yet regulations must penetrate everything. People are guided forward with benevolence and righteousness, restrained with punishments. Thus those with profound virtue receive honored positions; those with heavy merit receive glorious rewards. This serves to unify the empire and regulate the myriad people.
translations.idiomatic: Human affairs have myriad aspects, yet regulations must penetrate everything. People are guided forward with benevolence and righteousness, restrained with punishments. Thus those with profound virtue receive honored positions; those with heavy merit receive glorious rewards. This serves to unify the empire and regulate the myriad people.

translations.literal: Even Zi Xia, Confucius's most eminent disciple, still said: 'Going out I see the splendor and magnificence and am pleased; coming in I hear the Master's way and am joyful—these two battle in my heart, and I cannot decide myself.' Moreover, those of mediocre capacity and below gradually became soaked in lost teachings and clothed in established customs—what then?
translations.idiomatic: Confucius said "One must rectify names", but in Wei his residence was not in accord.

translations.literal: After Confucius passed away, his disciples who received his teachings sank into obscurity and were not raised up; some went to Qi or Chu, some entered the rivers and seas—how painful it is!
translations.idiomatic: When Qin possessed the world, they incorporated all the rites and ceremonies of the six states, selecting what was good, though not in accord with the sage's system, yet honoring the ruler and suppressing ministers, with the court full and proper, following the ancient ways.

translations.literal: The suburban fields reach to the Son of Heaven, the altars reach to the nobles, the enclosures extend to the scholars and grandees, so as to distinguish those who honor serve the honored, the lowly serve the lowly, those suitable for great have greatness, those suitable for small have smallness.
translations.idiomatic: Those who are rulers grasp the root and control the branches;

translations.chinese: 故有天下者事七世，有一國者事五世，有五乘之地者事三世，有三乘之地者事二世，有特牲而食者不得立宗廟，所以辨積厚者流澤廣，積薄者流澤狹也。
translations.literal: Thus those who possess the empire serve seven generations, those who possess one state serve five generations, those who possess five chariot lands serve three generations, those who possess three chariot lands serve two generations, those who have special victims and eat cannot establish ancestral temples, so as to distinguish those with thick accumulation have broad flowing favor, those with thin accumulation have narrow flowing favor.
translations.idiomatic: Those who are ministers grasp the branches and serve the root.

translations.chinese: 大饗上玄尊，俎上腥魚，先大羹，貴食飲之本也。
translations.literal: The great feast honors the supreme cup, the stands have raw fish, precede with great broth—honoring the root of food and drink.
translations.idiomatic: This is why rites flourish.

translations.chinese: 大饗上玄尊而用薄酒，食先黍稷而飯稻粱，祭嚌先大羹而飽庶羞，貴本而親用也。
translations.literal: The great feast honors the supreme cup but uses thin wine, food precedes millet and grain but rice with rice and millet, sacrifice bites precede great broth but sate with many delicacies—honoring the root but being close to use.
translations.idiomatic: Thus rites are the root;

context.next: 貴本之謂文，親用之謂理，兩者合而成文，以歸太一，是謂大隆。

translations.chinese: 貴本之謂文，親用之謂理，兩者合而成文，以歸太一，是謂大隆。
translations.literal: Honoring the root is called pattern, being close to use is called principle, the two combine to form pattern, to return to the great one, this is called great flourishing.
translations.idiomatic: Rulers serve the root;

context.previous: 大饗上玄尊而用薄酒，食先黍稷而飯稻粱，祭嚌先大羹而飽庶羞，貴本而親用也。

translations.chinese: 故尊之上玄尊也，俎之上腥魚也，豆之先大羹，一也。
translations.literal: Thus the supreme cup above the cups, raw fish above the stands, great broth first in the dishes—it is one.
translations.idiomatic: Ministers guard the branches;

translations.chinese: 利爵弗啐也，成事俎弗嘗也，三侑之弗食也。
translations.literal: Profitable cups are not sipped, completed matter stands are not tasted, the three toasts are not eaten.
translations.idiomatic: Loyalty and trustworthiness are the root of rites;

translations.chinese: 大昏之未廢齊也，大廟之未內尸也，始絕之未小斂，一也。
translations.literal: The great marriage has not yet dismissed the fasting hut, the great temple has not yet entered the corpse, beginning mourning has not yet small dressing—it is one.
translations.idiomatic: Honor and humility are the order of rites;

translations.chinese: 大路之素幬也，郊之麻絻，喪服之先散麻，一也。
translations.literal: The great chariot's plain canopy, the suburban hemp headbands, mourning garments first loose hemp—it is one.
translations.idiomatic: This is why rites are practiced.

translations.chinese: 三年哭之不反也，清廟之歌一倡而三嘆，縣一鐘尚拊膈，朱弦而通越，一也。
translations.literal: Three years of weeping do not return, pure temple songs one begins and three sigh, hanging one bell still strikes the frame, vermilion strings and penetrating tones—it is one.
translations.idiomatic: Thus honor and humility are what correct rites;

translations.chinese: 凡禮始乎脫，成乎文，終乎稅。
translations.literal: All rites begin with simplicity, are completed with pattern, end with relaxation.
translations.idiomatic: Root and branches are what strengthen rites.

context.next: 故至備，情文俱盡；

translations.chinese: 故至備，情文俱盡；
translations.literal: Thus in utmost completeness, emotion and pattern are both exhausted;
translations.idiomatic: Thus reaching full preparation, emotion and pattern are both exhausted;

context.previous: 凡禮始乎脫，成乎文，終乎稅。
context.next: 其次，情文代勝；

translations.chinese: 其次，情文代勝；
translations.literal: Next, emotion and pattern alternately prevail;
translations.idiomatic: Next, emotion and pattern take turns prevailing;

context.previous: 故至備，情文俱盡；
context.next: 其下，復情以歸太一。

translations.chinese: 其下，復情以歸太一。
translations.literal: Below this, return to emotion to go to the great one.
translations.idiomatic: Next, emotion and pattern take turns prevailing;

context.previous: 其次，情文代勝；

translations.chinese: 天地以合，日月以明，四時以序，星辰以行，江河以流，萬物以昌，好惡以節，喜怒以當。
translations.literal: Heaven and earth combine thereby, sun and moon are bright thereby, the four seasons are ordered thereby, stars and constellations move thereby, rivers and streams flow thereby, the myriad things flourish thereby, likes and dislikes are regulated thereby, joy and anger are appropriate thereby.
translations.idiomatic: Thus the knowledgeable adapt to customs, the worthy adapt to generations, the sages adapt to their persons.

context.next: 以為下則順，以為上則明。

translations.chinese: 以為下則順，以為上則明。
translations.literal: Using it below then follows, using it above then is enlightened.
translations.idiomatic: Thus the knowledgeable adapt to customs, the worthy adapt to generations, the sages adapt to their persons.

context.previous: 天地以合，日月以明，四時以序，星辰以行，江河以流，萬物以昌，好惡以節，喜怒以當。

translations.chinese: 太史公曰：至矣哉！
translations.literal: The Grand Historian said: How supreme!
translations.idiomatic: The Grand Historian says: How perfect!

context.next: 立隆以為極，而天下莫之能益損也。

translations.chinese: 立隆以為極，而天下莫之能益損也。
translations.literal: Established flourishing as the extreme, and the empire cannot add to or diminish it.
translations.idiomatic: Establishing the flourishing as the extreme, yet the world cannot add or subtract from it.

context.previous: 太史公曰：至矣哉！
context.next: 本末相順，終始相應，至文有以辨，至察有以說。

translations.chinese: 本末相順，終始相應，至文有以辨，至察有以說。
translations.literal: Root and branch are mutually compliant, beginning and end correspond, utmost pattern has distinctions, utmost examination has explanations.
translations.idiomatic: Thus if the noble man has no rites, though he has strong force, he cannot fulfill his duties;

context.previous: 立隆以為極，而天下莫之能益損也。
context.next: 天下從之者治，不從者亂；

translations.chinese: 天下從之者治，不從者亂；
translations.literal: The empire follows it and is ordered, does not follow it and is chaotic;
translations.idiomatic: As for possessing a state, it is not so.

context.previous: 本末相順，終始相應，至文有以辨，至察有以說。
context.next: 從之者安，不從者危。

translations.chinese: 從之者安，不從者危。
translations.literal: Follows it and is peaceful, does not follow it and is endangered.
translations.idiomatic: The world follows those who are ordered, those who do not follow are chaotic;

context.previous: 天下從之者治，不從者亂；
context.next: 小人不能則也。

translations.chinese: 小人不能則也。
translations.literal: Small men cannot emulate it.
translations.idiomatic: The world follows those who are ordered, those who do not follow are chaotic;

context.previous: 從之者安，不從者危。

translations.chinese: 禮之貌誠深矣，堅白同異之察，入焉而弱。
translations.literal: The appearance of rites is truly profound, the examination of hard white same different enters it and weakens.
translations.idiomatic: Thus it is said: "Rites, rites—what are jade and silk about!"

context.next: 其貌誠大矣，擅作典制褊陋之說，入焉而望。

translations.chinese: 其貌誠大矣，擅作典制褊陋之說，入焉而望。
translations.literal: Its appearance is truly great, the sayings of monopolizing creation of systems and narrow pettiness enter it and are daunted.
translations.idiomatic: It also says: "Feudal lords regard appointing feudal lords as favor, ministers and grand officers regard appointing ministers and grand officers as favor."

context.previous: 禮之貌誠深矣，堅白同異之察，入焉而弱。
context.next: 其貌誠高矣，暴慢恣睢，輕俗以為高之屬，入焉而隊。

translations.chinese: 其貌誠高矣，暴慢恣睢，輕俗以為高之屬，入焉而隊。
translations.literal: Its appearance is truly lofty, the violent rude unrestrained types who lightly regard customs as lofty enter it and collapse.
translations.idiomatic: Thus rites appear externally, loyalty and substance are internal.

context.previous: 其貌誠大矣，擅作典制褊陋之說，入焉而望。
context.next: 故繩誠陳，則不可欺以曲直；

translations.chinese: 故繩誠陳，則不可欺以曲直；
translations.literal: Thus when the cord is truly set out, it cannot be deceived with straight and crooked;
translations.idiomatic: Thus rites appear externally, loyalty and substance are internal.

context.previous: 其貌誠高矣，暴慢恣睢，輕俗以為高之屬，入焉而隊。
context.next: 衡誠縣，則不可欺以輕重；

translations.chinese: 衡誠縣，則不可欺以輕重；
translations.literal: When the balance is truly hung, it cannot be deceived with light and heavy;
translations.idiomatic: Thus it is said: "A person of loyalty and trustworthiness can study rites."

context.previous: 故繩誠陳，則不可欺以曲直；

translations.chinese: 規矩誠錯，則不可欺以方員；
translations.literal: When compass and square are truly applied, it cannot be deceived with square and round;
translations.idiomatic: Thus it is said: "A person of loyalty and trustworthiness can study rites."

context.previous: 衡誠縣，則不可欺以輕重；

translations.chinese: 君子審禮，則不可欺以詐偽。
translations.literal: The gentleman examines rites, cannot be deceived with fraud and falsehood.
translations.idiomatic: If there are no loyal and trustworthy people, then rites do not proceed without substance.

context.previous: 規矩誠錯，則不可欺以方員；
context.next: 故繩者，直之至也；

translations.chinese: 故繩者，直之至也；
translations.literal: Thus the cord is the utmost of straightness;
translations.idiomatic: Thus it is said: "Rites are appearance;

context.previous: 君子審禮，則不可欺以詐偽。
context.next: 衡者，平之至也；

translations.chinese: 衡者，平之至也；
translations.literal: The balance is the utmost of levelness;
translations.idiomatic: A person of loyalty and trustworthiness can study rites."

context.previous: 故繩者，直之至也；
context.next: 規矩者，方員之至也；

translations.chinese: 規矩者，方員之至也；
translations.literal: Compass and square are the utmost of squareness and roundness;
translations.idiomatic: Thus in ancient times those who studied rites must solidify their will, broaden their hearing, nurture their bodies, and only then enter.

context.previous: 衡者，平之至也；
context.next: 禮者，人道之極也。

translations.chinese: 禮者，人道之極也。
translations.literal: Rites are the extreme of the human way.
translations.idiomatic: Thus it is said: "The noble man in rites has complete emotion and caution, extends his reverence and is sincere as if there is beauty and pattern and sincerity, as if there is reverence and closeness, as if there is benevolence and warmth, as if there is support and humility."

context.previous: 規矩者，方員之至也；
context.next: 然而不法禮者不足禮，謂之無方之民；

translations.chinese: 然而不法禮者不足禮，謂之無方之民；
translations.literal: Yet those who do not follow rites are insufficient in rites, called people without direction;
translations.idiomatic: To regulate his interior,

context.previous: 禮者，人道之極也。
context.next: 法禮足禮，謂之有方之士。

translations.chinese: 法禮足禮，謂之有方之士。
translations.literal: Those who follow rites and suffice in rites are called scholars with direction.
translations.idiomatic: And complete his exterior,

context.previous: 然而不法禮者不足禮，謂之無方之民；
context.next: 禮之中，能思索，謂之能慮；

translations.chinese: 禮之中，能思索，謂之能慮；
translations.literal: Among rites, those who can contemplate are called able to consider;
translations.idiomatic: Harmonize his countenance,

context.previous: 法禮足禮，謂之有方之士。
context.next: 能慮勿易，謂之能固。

translations.chinese: 能慮勿易，謂之能固。
translations.literal: Able to consider and not change are called able to be firm.
translations.idiomatic: Weight his emotions and restraint,

context.previous: 禮之中，能思索，謂之能慮；
context.next: 能慮能固，加好之焉，聖矣。

translations.chinese: 能慮能固，加好之焉，聖矣。
translations.literal: Able to consider and able to be firm, moreover delight in it—sages.
translations.idiomatic: Order his dignity,

context.previous: 能慮勿易，謂之能固。
context.next: 天者，高之極也；

translations.chinese: 天者，高之極也；
translations.literal: Heaven is the extreme of height;
translations.idiomatic: Only thus can he become a complete person.

context.previous: 能慮能固，加好之焉，聖矣。
context.next: 地者，下之極也；

translations.chinese: 地者，下之極也；
translations.literal: Earth is the extreme of lowness;
translations.idiomatic: Thus it is said: "Rites are what people serve."

context.previous: 天者，高之極也；
context.next: 日月者，明之極也；

translations.chinese: 日月者，明之極也；
translations.literal: Sun and moon are the extreme of brightness;
translations.idiomatic: Thus without rites there is no way to be a person.

context.previous: 地者，下之極也；
context.next: 無窮者，廣大之極也；

translations.chinese: 無窮者，廣大之極也；
translations.literal: The infinite is the extreme of vastness;
translations.idiomatic: Thus it is said: "Rites are what people tread."

context.previous: 日月者，明之極也；
context.next: 聖人者，道之極也。

translations.chinese: 聖人者，道之極也。
translations.literal: Sages are the extreme of the way.
translations.idiomatic: Thus without rites there is no way to tread.

translations.chinese: 以財物為用，以貴賤為文，以多少為異，以隆殺為要。
translations.literal: Using wealth and goods for use, using noble and base as pattern, using many and few as distinction, using flourishing and diminishing as essentials.
translations.idiomatic: Thus the gentleman having obtained his nourishment, moreover delights in its distinctions.

context.next: 文貌繁，情欲省，禮之隆也；

translations.chinese: 文貌繁，情欲省，禮之隆也；
translations.literal: Pattern appearance elaborate, emotion desires few—this is rites' flourishing;
translations.idiomatic: Who knows that scholars going to death for integrity is the means to nourish life.

translations.chinese: 文貌省，情欲繁，禮之殺也；
translations.literal: Pattern appearance few, emotion desires elaborate—this is rites' diminishing;
translations.idiomatic: Who knows that light expenditure is the means to nourish wealth, who knows that respectful yielding is the means to nourish security, who knows that rites righteousness pattern principle is the means to nourish emotion.

translations.idiomatic: People if living as their view, those will certainly die;

translations.idiomatic: If laziness as security, those will certainly danger;

context.next: 人域是域，士君子也。

translations.chinese: 人域是域，士君子也。
translations.literal: This domain is domain, scholar gentlemen.
translations.idiomatic: If emotion prevailing as security, those will certainly perish.

context.previous: 步驟馳騁廣騖不外，是以君子之性守宮庭也。
context.next: 外是，民也。

translations.literal: Thus thickness is rites' accumulation;

context.next: 大者，禮之廣也；
